conclusion: Determine the height \( h_a \) from which the ball \( a \) is released such that it can just fly out from point \( D \).
The ball slides down the inclined rail \( PA \) under the influence of gravity.
The potential energy at height \( h_a \) is converted into kinetic energy at point \( A \).
The height difference between \( P \) and \( A \) is \( h_a \sin \theta \).
The horizontal distance from \( P \) to \( A \) is \( h_a \cos \theta \).
The ball slides along the horizontal rail \( AB \) and then enters the semicircular track \( BCD \).
The velocity at point \( A \) is \( v_A = \sqrt{2gh_a \sin \theta} \).
The velocity at point \( B \) is the same as the velocity at point \( A \) because there is no friction on the horizontal rail.
The velocity at point \( B \) is \( v_B = \sqrt{2gh_a \sin \theta} \).
The ball leaves the semicircular track at point \( D \) with just enough speed to fly out.
The normal force at point \( D \) is zero, so the centripetal force is provided by the electric force.
The centripetal force is given by \( \frac{mv_D^2}{R} \).
The electric force is \( qE \), where \( q \) is the charge of the ball.
For the ball to just fly out, the centripetal force must be equal to the electric force: \( \frac{mv_D^2}{R} = qE \).
Using conservation of mechanical energy from point \( B \) to point \( D \): \( \frac{1}{2}mv_B^2 = \frac{1}{2}mv_D^2 + mg \cdot 2R \).
Substituting \( v_B = \sqrt{2gh_a \sin \theta} \) and solving for \( v_D \): \( v_D^2 = 4gh_a \sin \theta - 4gR \).
